list.media_caption: Tony Velasquez, Kalibapi Family, comics series in Tribune, 18 Oct 1943
list.media_credit: Photo from Ateneo de Manila University Press
list.article_title: VA 1942 Gatbonton and Velasquez, Kalibapi Family
list.text_description: Liborio "Gat" Gatbonton and Tony Velasquez create illustrations for the Japanese-sponsored papers. The Kalibapi Family, a cartoon by Velasquez, exemplifies the Japanese policy of extolling Filipino virtues. (Photo from Ateneo de Manila University Press)

list.media_credit: Photo from Cultural Center of the Philippines Collection
list.text_description: Genesis by H. R. Ocampo is made into the tapestry show curtain of the Main Theater (later, Tanghalang Nicanor Abelardo) of the Cultural Center of the Philippines.

list.media_credit: Photo from Cultural Center of the Philippines Collection
list.text_description: Gomburza by Jaime de Guzman uses history to comment on contemporary issues by painting the martyrdom of the three priests killed by the Spanish colonizers in 1872.
Tikbalang by Solomon Saprid presents a metal sculpture of a half-man, half-horse being based on a Filipino folk belief.

list.media_credit: Photo from Cultural Center of the Philippines Collection
list.text_description: Bamboo Fugue by Francisco Verano, an example of bamboo sculpture, is created.

list.media_caption: Pasyon at Rebolusyon, Santiago Bose, 1983, Mixed media
list.text_description: Santi Bose creates the installation Pasyon at Rebolusyon, which explores the theme of nativist millenarian faith, using indigenous and organic materials. (Photo from Peggy Bose)

list.media_caption: Two Nuns of Edsa, Pete Reyes, 1986, The Manila Times
list.text_description: "Two Nuns of Edsa" by photojournalist Pete Reyes becomes an iconic image of the EDSA Revolt. (Photo from The Manila Times)
Lorenzo Atlas does the engraving of the La Naval. (Photo from Intramuros Administration Collection)

list.media_caption: Esteban Villanueva, Basi Revolt, 9th of 14 paintings depicting the bloody battle at Bantaoay, 1821
list.media_credit: Photo from National Museum of the Philippines collection
list.text_description: Esteban Villanueva is commissioned to do the Basi Revolt Series commemorating the Ilocano Basi revolt in 1807. (Photo from National Museum of the Philippines Collection)

list.media_caption: Juan Arceo/Juan Arzeo, Retrato de la Familia Azcarraga, 1824 Del Monte Collection
list.media_credit: Photo by Hugh Kelly, courtesy of Jose Campos III
list.text_description: Juan Arceo completes the Retrato de la familia Azcárraga, one of the earliest secular portraits in the Philippines. (Photo by Hugh Kelly, courtesy of Jose Campos III)

list.media_credit: San Agustin Museum/Photo by Kiko del Rosario
list.text_description: Kuan-Yin Nuestra Señora del Rosario, is created by Boholano painters, similar to the image of Kuanyin, the Chinese goddess of mercy. (San Agustin Museum/Photo by Kiko del Rosario)

list.media_caption: A page of illustrations from the Elementos de Perspectiva
list.media_credit: Photo from Miguel de Benavides Library, University of Santo Tomas
list.text_description: Nov 26: Elementos de Perspectiva, a manual of drawing and painting written in Spanish, is published in the Philippines. It influences painters on how to draw still life, render anatomy, and use perspective. (Photo from Miguel de Benavides Library, University of Santo Tomas)

list.article_title: VA 1850 Academia de Dibujo y Pintura
list.text_description: The Academia de Dibujo y Pintura re-opens and promotes the academic style of painting under Spanish teachers such as Agustin Saez and Lorenzo Rocha. A Filipino student Lorenzo Guerrero (in photo) eventually becomes a teacher.

list.media_caption: Jose Dans, El Cielo, El Paraiso, El Purgatorio y El Infierno, 1850
list.text_description: El Cielo, el Paraiso, el Purgatorio y el Infierno, a mural painting attributed to Jose Dans, is installed in Paete church; it is an example of a catechetical church painting.

list.media_credit: Photo from Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas Collection
list.text_description: Francisco Garcia Ortiz by Jose Honorato Lozano exemplifies the minituarized form of painting called letras y figuras patronized by the mestizo class and foreigners looking for souvenirs. (Photo from Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas Collection)
La Ilustracion Filipina, published 1859-1860, and 1882, features lithographs of landscapes and genre scenes by Filipino artists.

Antonio Malantic paints the portraits of Soledad Francia and Inocencia Francia (in photo), 1870, which depict young ladies of the mestizo class clothed in formal clothing with delicate embroidery. (Photo from Leandro V. Locsin Collection)

list.media_credit: Photo from Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas Collection
list.text_description: Using the miniaturismo style, Simon Flores paints Familia Quiason, 1880, detailing the embroidery of the clothes, jewelry, and interiors of the family home. (Photo from Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas Collection)

list.media_caption: Soterania Puson y Quintos de Ventenilla, Dionisio de Castro, 1892
list.media_credit: Photo from Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas Collection
list.text_description: Soterania Puson Y Quintos De Ventenilla, 1892, by Dionisio de Castro is an example of 19th century portraiture called miniaturismo, featuring the sitter wearing her jewelry and accoutrements. (Photo from Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas Collection)
Bodegon, 1884, by Paz Paterno features a landscape and still life of fruits.

list.media_credit: Photo from Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas Collection
list.text_description: Embroidery work using hair in embroidery of a landscape scene, such as the Country Scene by Adelaida Paterno, is taught in the colegios for women. Embroidery work using hair in embroidery of a landscape scene, such as the Country Scene by Adelaida Paterno, is taught in the colegios for women. (Photo from Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas Collection)

list.media_caption: Art nouveau four-poster bed by Eduardo Ah Tay
list.text_description: Ah Tay furniture becomes popular with its distinctive design for beds, cabinet, dining table and long seats. (Photo from Leon Gallery)

list.media_caption: Banton burial cloth, ca 14th-15th century, Abaca, Warp ikat
list.media_credit: Photo from National Museum of the Philippines Collection
list.text_description: Ikat weave becomes prevalent in Southeast Asia in the 14th - 15th century, as evidenced by the Banton Burial Cloth, found in Banton Cave, Romblon in 1939.

list.media_credit: Photo courtesy of the artist and ARNDT Fine Art
list.text_description: Nardong Tae by Louie Cordero is included in the exhibition The Philippine Contemporary: To Scale the Past and the Possible at the Metropolitan Museum of Manila.

list.media_caption: Inabel weaver Magdalena Gamayo, Gawad sa Manlilikha ng Bayan awardee, 2012
list.text_description: The Gawad Manlilikha ng Bayan is awarded to Magdalena Gamayo (Photo 1) for Ilocano inabel weaving and Teofilo Garcia (Photo 2) for kattukong hat making. (Photos by Renato S. Rastrollo, NCCA)

list.media_caption: Walang katapusang paghalo ng balat sa tinalupan, Brenda Fajardo, 1987
list.text_description: Brenda Fajardo receives the Gawad CCP para sa Sining. (Photo by Rolando Codes)

Kulo exhibit at the CCP is forced to close due to protests that arose with regards to Poleteismo (in photo) by Mideo Cruz, an installation work that juxtaposes religiosity and politics. (Photo from the artist)

list.media_caption: Martha Atienza, Gilubong ang Akon Pusod sa Dagat, 2011
list.text_description: Martha Atienza creates Gilubong Ang Akon Pusod Sa Dagat, a video art installation which juxtaposes the related lives of seafarers and the fishing community. The work wins the 2012 Ateneo Art Awards. (Photo from the artist)

list.media_caption: Kawayan de Guia in collaboration with Baguio community, Axis Tent, 2011
list.text_description: The AXIS Art Project is launched in Baguio City, initiated by artist Kawayan de Guia. AXIS focuses on projects such as art festivals evoking collective memory and communities.

list.media_credit: Photo from National Museum of the Philippines Collection
list.text_description: The Manunggul Jar (890-710 BCE), an earthenware pottery found in Palawan in the 1960s and featuring human figures rowing a boat, is used as a secondary burial jar. (Photo from National Museum of the Philippines Collection)

list.media_caption: Maitum Jar No. 21, 5 BCE to CE 225 and CE 70 to 370
list.media_credit: Photo from National Museum of the Philippines Collection
list.text_description: Maitum pottery, dated 5 BCE to CE 225 and AD 70 to 370, a period straddling the Philippine Late Neolithic and Early Metal Age, is used as anthropomorphic secondary burial jars. These are discovered in 1992-95, in Sarangani Province in Mindanao. (Photo from National Museum of the Philippines Collection)

list.media_caption: Balanghai CE 320, cabo negro, Ambangan, Libertad, Butuan, Agusan del Norte Province, northeastern Mindanao.
list.text_description: Balanghai boats, dated 320 CE, are used for trade, as seen in archaeological excavation in Butuan, Agusan del Norte. (Photo by Roezielle Joy Iglesia)

list.media_credit: Photo courtesy of Oriental Ceramic Society of the Philippines
list.text_description: Chinese porcelain and stoneware are traded in the Philippines during the Sung and Yuan periods, and this trade reaches its apex in the 13th century. (Photo from Oriental Ceramic Society of the Philippines)

list.media_credit: Photo by John Weinstein, The Field Museum, Image No. A114678d_006A, Cat. No. 109928
list.text_description: The Golden Tara of Agusan, crafted in the late 13th century and found in 1917, exemplifies the Hindu - Buddhist links of the period. (Photo by John Weinstein, The Field Museum)

list.media_caption: Oton Death Mask, late 14th to early 15th century, gold
list.media_credit: Photo from National Museum of the Philippines Collection
list.text_description: Gold ornaments such as jewelry is included in ancient burial customs. Gold sheet is also used as face covers, such as the Oton Death Mask, dated late 15th century, and found in 1973. (Photo from National Museum of the Philippines Collection)

list.media_caption: Green nephrite lingling-o and double animal-headed ear pendants from the Tabon Caves in Palawan.
list.media_credit: Photo from National Museum of the Philippines Collection
list.text_description: Jade Ling-ling-o, an ornament made from Fengtian jade from Taiwan, comes to Batanes. Early Filipinos developed a style of jade carving, exemplified by the ling-ling-o found in Uyaw Cave, Palawan (ca 500-300 BCE). (Photo from National Museum of the Philippines Collection)

list.media_caption: Our Lady of Peace and Good Voyage, NUESTRA SEÑORA DE LA PAZ Y BUEN VIAJE Aka Birhen ng Antipolo, early 17th
list.text_description: The image of the Virgin Mary called Nuestra Señora de la Paz y Buenviaje, popularly known as Birhen ng Antipolo, is brought by Gov Gen Juan Niño de Taborato to the Philippines in 1626 from a parish in Acapulco. (Photo from Nicanor G. Tiongson)

list.media_caption: Doctrina Christiana en la Lengua Española y Tagala, 1593
list.text_description: Doctrina Christiana, the first book printed in the Philippines using the xylographic method, is printed in both Spanish and Tagalog. It contains the illustration of Santo Domingo by a Chinese convert Juan de Vera. (Photo from CCP)

list.media_caption: Our Lady of La Naval, detail, (Lady of the Navy) aka Nuestra Señora del Santisimo Rosario (Our Lady of the Most Holy Rosary). 1593
list.media_credit: Photo courtesy of Santo Domingo Church Library
list.text_description: La Naval, a sculptural image of the Virgin Mary made of wood and ivory, is carved by a Chinese artisan from Ilocos. Products of the ivory carving tradition are eventually exported to Europe. (Photo courtesy of Santo Domingo Church Library)

list.media_credit: Photo from Boxer Codex, The Lilly Library Digital Collections
list.text_description: The Boxer Codex, ca 1590, depicts types of Filipinos in contemporary dress. It is believed to have been done by Chinese artisans. One image, the Pintados of the Visayas, features body tattoos as a form of dress. Photo: Depiction of the Bisaya, ca 1590 (Boxer Codex, The Lilly Library Digital Collections)

list.media_caption: Main retablo and altar of Silang church, Silang Retablos, 1671, Nuestra Señora de Candelaria Church
list.media_credit: Photo from Fr Marty Dimaranan and Phillip Medina, Silang Parish Council for Culture and Heritage
list.text_description: 1671: The Silang retablo features elements from Spanish, Mexican, Asian and native artistic traditions; it features the plateresque style of carving and the use of Solomonic columns. (Photo from Fr Marty Dimaranan and Phillip Medina, Silang Parish Council for Culture and Heritage)

list.media_caption: Our Lady of Prompt Help, NUESTRA SEÑORA DE PRONTO SOCORRO, 1585
list.media_credit: Photos courtesy of Santiago A. Pilar Library
list.text_description: Chinese artisans who were conscripted to paint religious images, such as the Nuestra Señora de Pronto Socorro, 1585, feature Chinese sensibilities in rendering the Virgin Mary’s face and drapery. (Photo from Santiago A. Pilar)

list.media_caption: Facade details of Church of Santo Tomas de Villanueva in Miag-ao, Iloilo, 2013
list.media_credit: Photo by Betty Lalana and Lino Arboleda, Ortigas Foundation Library Collection
list.text_description: The relief carving on the façade of Miag-ao Church in Iloilo, done in 1787, indigenizes the rococo tradition, as it features local plants, such as a banana and a coconut tree, in its facade carvings. (Photo by Betty Lalana and Lino Arboleda, Ortigas Foundation Library, 2013)

list.media_caption: IESVS es clauado enla Cruz), Copper engraving by Nicolas de la Cruz Bagay, 1760
list.text_description: In the fifth edition (1760) of Gaspar Aquino de Belen’s pasyon, Nicolas de la Cruz Bagay and Francisco Suarez engrave illustrations of Christ’s life and passion.

list.media_caption: Print by Francisco Rodriguez depicting the tortures of hell, Ang Infiernong Nabubucsan sa Tauong Christiano, 1713
list.media_credit: Photo from National Library of the Philippines Collection
list.text_description: The images of hell are engraved by Francisco Dominguez in the popular cathetical book Ang Infiernong Nabubucsan sa Taong Cristiano at Nang Houag Masoc Doon. (Print from National Library of the Philippines)

list.media_caption: Felix Resurreccion Hidalgo, La Banca, 1876 Eleuterio M. Pascual Collection
list.text_description: La Banca by Felix Resurreccion Hidalgo (1855-1913) is chosen for the Philadelphia Universal Exposition. (Photo by Kiko del Rosario)
The Pan-ay Bell is cast by Juan Reina in Pan-ay, Capiz. Commissioned by Fr Jose Beloso, the bell is reputed to be the largest in Asia. (Photo by Iannekleina)

list.media_caption: Felix Resurreccion Hidalgo, El Asesinato del Gobernador Bustamante y su Hijo, detail, late 19th century
list.text_description: El Asesinato del Gobernador Fernando Bustamante Y Su Hijo, painted in the late 19th century by Hidalgo, depicts an anti-clerical subject matter which echoes ilustrado discourse on church corruption and governance. (Photo by Kiko del Rosario)

list.media_caption: Las Virgenes Cristianas Expuestas Al Populacho, Felix Resurreccion Hidalgo, 1884
list.text_description: Spoliarium by Luna and Hidalgo’s Virgenes Christianas Expuestas al Populacho (in photo) are interpreted as alluding to the oppression of the Philippine colony by Spain. (Photo by Kiko del Rosario)

list.media_caption: Main altar of the San Ignacio Church, from 150: The Ateneo Way by Jose S. Arcilla, SJ, 1937
list.media_credit: Photo from 150: The Ateneo Way by Jose S. Arcilla, SJ. Media Wise Communications / Muse Books, 2009.
list.text_description: The work of Isabelo Tampinco in the San Ignacio Church, especially its interior decorations carved from 1882 to 1889, is hailed as a masterpiece in Philippine sculpture. (Photo from 150: The Ateneo Way by Jose S. Arcilla SJ, Media Wise Communications / Muse Books, 2009)

list.media_credit: Photo from University of the Philippines Jorge B. Vargas Museum collection
list.text_description: Primeras Letras by Simon Flores exemplifies genre paintings in the academic style. (Photo from University of the Philippines Jorge B. Vargas Museum collection)

list.media_caption: Photograph of a Wedding, Felix Laureano, Recuerdos de Filipinas, 1895
list.text_description: Recuerdos de Filipinas by Felix Laureano is the first collection of photographs by a Filipino. It features genre scenes and dress at the time. (Photo from Digital Library @ Villanova University)

list.media_caption: Harry Harnish, Captain Alex Davis’ Child and Nurse, Between 1898 and 1907. Photo no. 27 of the album “Poses and Exposures,”
list.media_credit: The Philippines Through the Lens of an American Soldier: The Harry Harnish Photographic Collection.
list.text_description: American photographer Harry Harnish takes photos of locals from 1898 to 1907. Photo: "Captain Alex Davis’ Child and Nurse" by Harry Harnish

list.media_credit: The Philippines Past and Present by Dean Worcester. The MacMillan Company, 1914.
list.text_description: Photo-ethnography provides images of Filipinos as “primitive” under the auspices of Commissioner Dean Worcester from 1902 to 1907. Photo: Bagobo community (Photo from The Philippines Past and Present by Dean Worcester, The MacMillan Company, 1914)
In the spirit of Filipinization, western iconography is appropriated through the Virgen ng Balintawak, ca 1905, of the Aglipayan church. (Photo courtesy of Nicanor G. Tiongson)

list.media_caption: Norberto Roldan, The Matriarch and The Wedding in Negros (diptych), 1989
list.text_description: The Green Papaya Art Projects is founded by Norberto Roldan, Donna Miranda, Manny Chaves, and curator Bobi Valenzuela, as a project space envisioning experimentation in art in a non-commercial venture.

list.media_credit: Photo from the Presidential Communications Development and Strategic Planning Office
list.text_description: Jul 22: Philippine Free Press publishes the editorial cartoon "Military Rule Next?" by EZ Izon. (Photo from the Presidential Communications Development and Strategic Planning Office)

list.media_caption: San Clemente Festival/ The Fluvial Festival of Angono, Jose Blanco, 1984
list.media_credit: Photo from Lopez Museum and Library Collection
list.text_description: Folk genre paintings flourish in Angono, Tanay, and Binangonan, giving rise to painters such as Jose Blanco, Salvador Juban, Nemesio Miranda, and Vicente Reyes. (Photo from Lopez Museum and Library Collection)
Tingguians by Manuel Rodriguez Jr explores tapestry work and printmaking. (Photo from Marcelino Rodriguez)

list.media_caption: Turn of the Century, Gilda Cordero-Fernando, Nik Ricio
list.text_description: The book Turn of the Century is published, edited by Gilda Cordero-Fernando and designed by Nik Ricio. (Photo from GCF Books)

list.media_caption: Antipas Delotavo, Itak sa Puso ni Mang Juan, 1978
list.article_title: VA 1978-86 Ang Itak sa Puso ni Mang Juan
list.text_description: Ang Itak sa Puso ni Mang Juan by Antipas Delotavo is painted to show the plight of Filipino workers oppressed by multinational companies.

list.media_caption: Juan Luna, The Filipino as Painter, Santiago Albano Pilar
list.media_credit: Photo of book cover courtesy of Eugenio Lopez Foundation, Inc
list.article_title: VA 1980 Juan Luna: The Filipino as Painter
list.text_description: Santiago Pilar writes Juan Luna: The Filipino as Painter, published by the Eugenio Lopez Foundation. (Photo from Eugenio Lopez Foundation, Inc)
Wood Thingsby Junyee exemplifies installation art made of kapok or cotton pods, installed on the walls and floor of the CCP. (Photo by Kiko del Rosario)

list.media_caption: Felix Resurreccion Hidalgo, Per Pacem et Libertatem, study
list.text_description: Per Pacem et Libertatem by Hidalgo is installed in a government building in Manila by December 1907. It is destroyed in 1945. (Photo from Eugenio Lopez Foundation collection)

Homenaje del Pueblo Filipino a los Heroes del ’96 aka Cry of Balintawak by Ramon Martinez becomes the first concrete full-figure sculpture of a revolutionary figure, assumed to be the figure of Andres Bonifacio. The sculpture has been installed in UP Diliman since 1967. (Photo by Kiko del Rosario)

list.media_caption: The University of the Philippines College of Fine Arts first director, Fabian de la Rosa, seated, with eminent professors, left to right: Pablo Amorsolo, Irineo Miranda, Teodoro Buenaventura, Toribio Herrera, Ramon Peralta Sr, Vicente Rivera y Mir, Guillermo Tolentino, Fernando Amorsolo, and Ambrosio Morales
list.text_description: Fabian de la Rosa (in photo, seated) goes to Europe in 1908-1910 under a pensionado scholarship. He joins the faculty of UP School of Fine Arts and will later become its director (1925-35), after Rafael Enriquez.

The Rizal Monument by Richard Kissling is installed at the Luneta Park in Manila. His design is replicated in reinforced concrete in the public plazas of towns and cities throughout the 1910s to the 1930s. (Photo by Kiko del Rosario).

list.media_credit: Copyright owned by Fernando C. Amorsolo Art Foundation, Inc
list.text_description: Fabian de la Rosa and Fernando Amorsolo paint their own versions of Planting Rice, presenting an idealized view of peasant life. Landscape and genre paintings continue to be popular for the tourist market and art patrons. Photo: Fabian de la Rosa's Planting Rice

Guillermo Tolentino creates the Bonifacio Monument, installed at Caloocan. It features a sculptural tableau of the events from the 1872 execution of the GomBurZa to the 1896 Katipunan Revolution, with Bonifacio at its head flanked by Emilio Jacinto and other revolutionaries.

list.media_caption: Diosdado Lorenzo, Rape and Massacre in Ermita, 1947
list.text_description: Artists, liberated from the Japanese, paint artworks that document the war: Doomed Family, 1945, by Dominador Castañeda; Capas, 1948, by Demetrio Diego; Rape and Massacre in Ermita (in photo), Atrocities in Paco, and Execution at the Cemetery by Diosdado Lorenzo, all in 1947.

list.media_credit: Photos from the Dennis S. Villegas Collection, komiksph, and The Life and Art of Francisco Coching by Patrick Flores et al. Vibal Foundation, 2009
list.text_description: Don Ramon Roces and Tony Velasquez organize Ace Publications which puts out Pilipino Komiks, 1947, Tagalog Klasiks, 1949; Hiwaga Komiks, 1950; and Espesyal Komiks and Kenkoy Komiks, 1952. These comic books flourish until the 1980s. Some stories from the komiks eventually are adopted into films.
Cesar Legaspi paints The Gadgets, evoking human labor and its dehumanization in an industrial setting. (Photo from Lucila Salazar Collection)

Kaganapan by Napoleon Abueva wins the grand prize at the Art Association of the Philippines (AAP) annual competition and is considered a breakthrough in Philippine sculpture, as it veers away from the classical traditions and employs neorealism in its figuration.

list.media_credit: Photo from Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas Collection
list.text_description: Modern artists explore rooted expression modes such as Filipino-themed surrealism, as in Galo Ocampo’s Flagellants (Photo from Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas Collection).

Job Was Also Man by Martino Abellana wins first prize in the conservative category at the 1953 semiannual competition of the Art Association of the Philippines (AAP). (Photo from Romulo Galicano Collection)
Benedicto Cabrera aka BenCab begins creating the Larawan and Sabel series, exploring the image of the marginalized people in Philippine society, and contrasting the past with the present.

Performance art is done by the Arts Laboratory group composed of David Medalla, Jun Terra, Lazaro Soriano, Marciano Galang, Alan Rivera, and Red Mansueto. The works are improvisational and participatory, and done unannounced in public places and open spaces.

list.media_caption: Larry Alcala, Slice of Life, 1983, UP Diliman
list.text_description: Larry Alcala, Mauro Malang Santos, Corky Trinidad, Nonoy Marcelo, and Danilo Dalena are the most active in the field of komiks, creating witty satire on the political and social conditions of the country.

list.media_caption: Carlos V. Francisco, Filipino Struggles Through History, detail, 1964
list.text_description: Filipino Struggles Through History by Carlos “Botong” Francisco is installed at the City of Manila Katipunan Hall, depicting the visual narrative of the history of Manila on all four walls. Photo: Detail of Filipino Struggles... (Manila City Hall)

list.media_credit: Photo from Cultural Center of the Philippines Collection
list.text_description: Allegorical Harpoon by Napoleon Abueva, a modernist who challenged conventions in classical sculpture, is created and later acquired by the CCP.

list.media_caption: J. Elizalde Navarro, Homage to Dodgie Laurel, 1966
list.text_description: Homage to Dodgie Laurel by J. Elizalde Navarro is an assemblage using found objects and metal parts. (Photo from Ateneo Art Gallery Collection)
Crucifixion, an expressionistic image of the tortured human condition, is painted by Ang Kiukok.

The colossal Marcos Monument is created by the government in La Union, in the ancestral lands of the Ibaloi. It is damaged in 1989 by a blast reportedly done by the New People’s Army. It is subsequently destroyed in 2002 by bomb blasts from suspected treasure hunters. (Photo courtesy of Nicanor G. Tiongson)

Protest art intensifies with paintings and murals exhibited at the first Makiisa Festival. Social realist paintings are done, like Renato Habulan’s large-scale painting Kagampan, depicting the struggle of workers and peasants, Baens Santos’s Malumbay si Ina (in photo), and Doloricon’s Hinagpis.

Protest art continues with Pablo Baens Santos’s Alay sa Bagong Bayani and Edgar Talusan Fernandez’s Hanap ay Laya, both expressing the people’s aspiration for freedom and sovereignty. The clenched fist motif becomes popular in symbolizing militancy and defiance, as in Al Manrique’s Hand Series.
Jak en Poy, a playful interpretation of the historic EDSA Revolt by Lazaro Soriano, is painted.

list.media_caption: Uma ti Biag/Archetype, A Cordillera Labyrinth, Roberto Villanueva, 1989
list.media_credit: Photo from Japan Foundation and Angel Velasco Shaw
list.text_description: Roberto Villanueva installs the open-air labyrinth Uma ti Biag at the CCP grounds. (Photo from Japan Foundation and Angel Velasco Shaw)

list.media_credit: Photo from Cultural Center of the Philippines Collection
list.text_description: H.R. Ocampo receives the National Artist award.
Sinaunang Habi: Philippine Ancestral Weave is authored by Marian Pastor Roces, with photography by Dick Baldovino and Wig Tysman. (Photo from Nikki Books)
UGATLahi, a collective of progressive artists and activists, is founded. Photo: UGATLahi's Manananggal, 2007 (Photo from UGATLahi)

list.media_caption: Sanggawa Art Collective, Epilogo, 1998 Del Monte Collection
list.media_credit: Photo from of Mark Justiniani and Joy Mallari
list.text_description: Sanggawa Art Collective (1994 -2000) is organized by Elmer Borlongan, Karen Flores, Mark Justiniani, Joy Mallari, and Federico Sievert. It aims to revitalize mural art through collective work. Photo: Sanggawa's Epilogo, 1998 (Photo from Mark Justiniani and Joy Mallari).

list.media_caption: Felix Resurreccion Hidalgo and the Generation of 1872, Alfredo Roces
list.text_description: Alfredo Roces publishes Felix Resurrecion Hidalgo and the Generation of 1872. (Photo from Eugenio Lopez Foundation, Inc).
Antipas Delotavo paints Dantaon, which offers a critical view of the narrative of Philippine history.

list.media_caption: Painting History, revisions in philippine colonial art, Patrick D. Flores
list.article_title: VA 1998 Painting History: Revisions in Philippine Colonial Art
list.text_description: Painting History: Revisions in Philippine Colonial Art by Patrick Flores is published, offering a postcolonial perspective in reading Philippine art. (Photo from NCCA)

list.media_caption: Bagobo inabal weaver, Salinta Monon, Gawad sa Manililikha ng Bayan awardee, 1998
list.text_description: Salinta Monon (in photo) and Lang Dulay receive the Gawad Manlilikha ng Bayan award for Bagobo textile weaving and Tboli t’nalak weaving, respectively. (Photo by Renato S. Rastrollo, NCCA)

list.media_caption: Protest/Revolutionary Art in the Philippine 1970-1990, Alice G. Guillermo
list.article_title: VA 2001 Protest: Revolutionary Art in the Philippines
list.text_description: Alice Guillermo writes Protest: Revolutionary Art in the Philippines, 1970-1990, an important contribution in establishing the history of the art of the protest movement in the Philippines. (Photo from UP Press)

list.media_caption: Neo-Angono Art Collective, Sangandaan ng Kasaysayan ng Malayang Pamamahayag sa Pilipinas, 2007, original mural, top, and altered portions
list.text_description: The Neo-Angono Artists Collective is founded in Rizal province with members who are visual artists, writers, musicians, theater workers, filmmakers, critics, and researchers. They organize the Neo-Angono Public Art Festival annually which features installation pieces and performance art.

The video installation Ocular by Poklong Anading (1975) is exhibited in Some Rooms held at Osage Gallery. It explores the condition of migrant workers in Hong Kong. The video installation Ocular by Poklong Anading is exhibited in Some Rooms held at Osage Gallery. It explores the condition of migrant workers in Hong Kong. (Photo from the artist)

list.media_caption: Vicente Alvarez Dizon, After the Day’s Toil, 1938
list.text_description: After a Day’s Toil by Vicente Alvarez Dizon wins the top prize in the Golden Gate International Exposition, California in 1939. It wins over 77 other artworks, including that of Salvador Dali. (Photo from Josie Dizon Henson)

list.media_credit: Photo from University of Santo Tomas Museum Collection
list.text_description: Brown Madonna by Galo Ocampo indigenizes the theme of Madonna and Child. (University of Santo Tomas Museum Collection)

Weekly publications of Lipang Kalabaw, Philippines Free Press, and El Renacimiento, or dailies like The Independent, feature illustration work for editorial cartoons and artworks by Filipino artists. (Photo from Biblioteca Nacional de España)

list.media_caption: Album ng Kabalbalan ni Kenkoy, Tony Velasquez, Pre-World War II Kenkoy comic strip published in Liwayway
list.media_credit: Photo from Ateneo de Manila University Rizal Library
list.text_description: Antonio S. Velasquez and Romualdo Ramos publish the first issue of Album ng Mga Kabalbalan ni Kenkoy in Liwayway magazine. (Photo from Ateneo de Manila University Rizal Library)
The underground cultural magazine, Ulos, begins publication, and well-known social realists serve as illustrators. (Photo from Nicanor G. Tiongson Collection)

list.media_caption: Nicolas de la Cruz Bagay and Francisco Suarez, Murillo Velarde Map of 1734, CARTA HYDROGRAPHICA Y CHOROGRAPHICA DE LAS YSLAS FILIPINAS
list.text_description: Carta hydrographica y chorographica de las Yslas Filipinas, drawn by Fr Pedro Murillo Velarde, is printed, using four copper plates. Nicolas Dela Cruz Bagay and Francisco Suarez use the technique of copper engraving for the Map of 1734 and 1744 and their marginal vignettes. (Photo from Library of Congress)
Roberto Feleo creates the installation work Tau-Tao, using the traditional pinalakpak process in creating figures based on Bagobo mythology. (Photo from Galeri Nasional Indonesia)
Judy Freya Sibayan starts the performance Scapular Gallery Nomad, a concept-based work performed anywhere and anytime, as a project of institutional critique. (Photo from the artist).
Nov 30: The effigy Erapzilla by UGATLahi is used in a protest rally and the Welgang Bayan organized by the Erap Resign Movement and Bagong Alyansang Makabayan. (Photo from UGATLahi)
Kublai Milan creates The Durian, a monumental sculpture done in concrete, for the Davao International Airport. (Photo from the artist)

Robot Gamelan Quartet (in photo) by Tad Ermitaño is included in the exhibition of the 2008 International Symposium on Electronic Art (ISEAS2008) and exhibited in the National Museum of Singapore. (Photo by Joel Ong)

list.media_caption: Filipinos Ilustres, lithographic print, Jorge Pineda, based on drawing by Guillermo Tolentino, 1911
list.text_description: Filipinos Ilustres by Guillermo Tolentino, a fictive group portrait of the heroes and martyrs of the revolution, is drawn. This is later translated into a lithograph by Jorge Pineda and printed by Carmelo and Bauermann. (Photo from Nicanor G. Tiongson Collection)
Guillermo Tolentino makes the Oblation, which becomes the symbol of the University of the Philippines. (Photo from Jefferson Villacruz)
El Indio by Francisco Coching, a komiks story featuring a salakot-wearing hero, is published in Pilipino Komiks.

list.media_credit: Photo from University of Washington Department of Architecture
list.text_description: David Medalla’s Cloud Canyons No. 2 aka Bubble Machines, a mixed media work which exemplifies avant-garde art, is presented in England. (Photo from University of Washington Department of Architecture)

list.media_caption: Danilo Dalena, Tres-Seis Dejado, from the Jai-alai series
list.text_description: Danny Dalena starts his Jai Alai series, which he explores until 1990. The ball game with the aspect of betting is used as metaphor for the human condition in time of crisis in the Philippines.
Vietnam War, a photograph by Willie Vicoy, becomes an iconic image of that war, after its publication in Newsweek Magazine and Time Magazine. (Photo courtesy of Getty Images)
Carlos Villa does performance art in Ritual, exploring issues of race and multi-culturalism among the migrants in America. (Photo from Tymar Productions)

list.media_caption: Jose Tence Ruiz, Erding Erdrayb at Ang Kanyang Palasyong Agaw-Tanaw
list.text_description: Erding Erdrayb at ang Kanyang Palasyong Agaw-Tanaw is an assemblage created by Jose Tence Ruiz, inspired by the survivalist way of life of a jeepney driver. (Photo from the artist)

list.media_credit: Photo courtesy of the Bancroft Library, University of California, Berkeley
list.text_description: Joel Abong photograph by Kim Komenich is circulated internationally, drawing attention to the plight of the sugar workers in Negros. (Photo from The Regents of the University of California, The Bancroft Library, University of California, Berkeley)

Madonna of the Slums by Vicente Manansala, a key modernist painting that appropriates cubism to depict the poverty of the slum areas which arose after World War II, is painted. (Photo courtesy of Ronna Manansala)

Imelda Cajipe-Endaya starts the Mga Ninuno series, 1976-1979. The prints explore images from The Boxer Codex, 19th-century engravings and novenas, and Damian Domingo's albums, as commentary on Philippine society. Photo: Mga Ninuno VIII, 1979 (Photo by Kiko del Rosario)
Thinking Nude, a terra-cotta sculpture by Julie Lluch, explores a feminist trajectory in her art practice. (Photo from Singapore National Heritage Board)

Alfredo Esquillo paints Mamakinley as a critique of Philippine-US relations and is lauded at the Whitney Museum of American Art’s 2003 exhibition The American Effect: Global Perspectives on the United States 1990-2003. (Photo from the artist)

list.media_caption: Project M201: In God We Trust, Alfredo Juan, Isabel Aquilizan, 2003
list.text_description: Project M201: In God We Trust by Alfredo Juan and Isabel Aquilizan is exhibited as part of the 50th Venice Biennale, which offers a rethinking of the jeepney as representation of Filipino culture. (Photo from The Drawing Room)
